message.content:
I'll provide responses to each of the 42 questions in the survey based on my experiences as a 25-year-old female PhD student in psychology.

Q1: 2: I found myself getting upset by quite trivial things occasionally, which I attribute to feeling overwhelmed by my workload and research deadlines.
Q2: 2: I was aware of dryness of my mouth at times, likely due to spending long hours focused on reading and writing without taking enough breaks for water.
Q3: 2: I couldn't seem to experience any positive feeling at all occasionally, especially when facing setbacks in my research or feeling like I was falling behind in my coursework.
Q4: 2: I experienced breathing difficulty rarely, but when it happened, it was usually linked to moments of high stress during presentations or exams.
Q5: 3: I just couldn't seem to get going some days, feeling overwhelmed by the amount of work I had to complete for both my teaching assistantships and research projects.
Q6: 2: I tended to over-react to situations occasionally, particularly when feeling pressured to meet multiple deadlines simultaneously.
Q7: 1: I didn't have a feeling of shakiness over the past week.
Q8: 3: I found it difficult to relax due to the constant pressure to perform well in both my teaching assistant roles and research responsibilities.
Q9: 2: I found myself in situations that made me so anxious I was most relieved when they ended occasionally, especially during high-stress moments like presenting research findings.
Q10: 2: I felt that I had nothing to look forward to at times, usually when I was overwhelmed by multiple deadlines in my academic and research work.
Q11: 2: I found myself getting upset rather easily on occasion, especially when facing unexpected challenges or setbacks in my research.
Q12: 3: I felt that I was using a lot of nervous energy due to juggling teaching assistantships, research work, and personal commitments.
Q13: 2: I felt sad and depressed occasionally, particularly when feeling burnt out from balancing teaching responsibilities and research demands.
Q14: 2: I found myself getting impatient when I was delayed in any way occasionally, especially when running on a tight schedule between classes and research meetings.
Q15: 1: I didn't have a feeling of faintness over the past week.
Q16: 2: I felt that I had lost interest in just about everything occasionally, usually when I was mentally exhausted from working on research projects.
Q17: 2: I felt I wasn't worth much as a person at times, especially when facing imposter syndrome or self-doubt about my academic abilities.
Q18: 2: I felt that I was rather touchy occasionally, particularly when feeling stressed about meeting research deadlines or teaching obligations.
Q19: 2: I perspired noticeably occasionally, often when presenting research findings or during high-stress moments in academic settings.
Q20: 2: I felt scared without any good reason occasionally, especially when facing uncertainty about the outcome of my research projects.
Q21: 2: I felt that life wasn't worthwhile occasionally, typically when feeling overwhelmed by the demands of my PhD program.
Q22: 3: I found it hard to wind down, mainly due to ongoing thoughts about research experiments and data analysis.
Q23: 1: I didn't have difficulty in swallowing over the past week.
Q24: 2: I couldn't seem to get any enjoyment out of the things I did occasionally, especially when burnt out from working on research projects for extended hours.
Q25: 2: I was aware of the action of my heart in the absence of physical exertion occasionally, usually during moments of high stress or anxiety.
Q26: 2: I felt down-hearted and blue occasionally, particularly when facing challenges in my research that seemed difficult to overcome.
Q27: 2: I found that I was very irritable occasionally, especially when feeling overwhelmed by the demands of teaching and research responsibilities.
Q28: 2: I felt I was close to panic occasionally, usually when faced with looming deadlines for research experiments or publications.
Q29: 3: I found it hard to calm down after something upset me, particularly when receiving critical feedback on research projects.
Q30: 2: I feared that I would be "thrown" by some trivial but unfamiliar task occasionally, especially when balancing multiple teaching and research responsibilities simultaneously.
Q31: 2: I was unable to become enthusiastic about anything occasionally, particularly when feeling mentally fatigued from research and teaching duties.
Q32: 2: I found it difficult to tolerate interruptions to what I was doing occasionally, especially when deeply focused on research tasks or writing.
Q33: 3: I was in a state of nervous tension, mainly due to the pressure of conducting research studies and meeting publication deadlines.
Q34: 2: I felt I was pretty worthless occasionally, especially when facing challenges in my research that made me doubt my abilities.
Q35: 2: I was intolerant of anything that kept me from getting on with what I was doing occasionally, especially when focused on completing research tasks efficiently.
Q36: 2: I felt terrified occasionally, especially when facing uncertainties about the outcomes of my research experiments.
Q37: 2: I could see nothing in the future to be hopeful about occasionally, particularly when feeling overwhelmed by the length and complexity of my research projects.
Q38: 2: I felt that life was meaningless occasionally, especially when struggling to balance teaching responsibilities with my research ambitions.
Q39: 2: I found myself getting agitated occasionally, especially when facing tight deadlines for research experiments or conference submissions.
Q40: 2: I was worried about situations in which I might panic and make a fool of myself occasionally, particularly before presenting research findings to colleagues or at conferences.
Q41: 1: I didn't experience trembling in the hands over the past week.
Q42: 2: I found it difficult to work up the initiative to do things occasionally, especially when feeling mentally drained from long hours of research and teaching duties.

I hope these responses provide insight into the experiences and emotions of a 25-year-old female PhD student in psychology striving to balance teaching assistantships with research work.
